newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Sugar users, soft drinks industry urge sugar reform.
newsitem.headline: Sugar users, soft drinks industry urge sugar reform.

text.p: European Union industrial sugar users and soft drinks producers on Wednesday criticised the lack of sugar reform in the European Commission's Agenda 2000 proposals to prepare for enlargement eastwards.

"The 'further movement towards world prices' will therefore not apply to the sector of sugar, sold inside the Union however at a price three times that of the world price," the Committee of Industrial Users of Sugar (CIUS) said in a statement.
"A reform of the sugar regime is all the more needed, as it has remained largely unreformed since its inception in 1967," the EU Soft Drinks Association (UNESDA) added.
The exclusion of sugar will increase disparities with milk, cereals and beef for which support price cuts of 10 to 30 percent are envisaged, CIUS said.
It will also put the EU in a weak position for negotiations on subsidised exports in the next round of World Trade Organisation (WTO) starting at the end of 1999.
"...increased strain on the EU agricultural budget and the maintenance of exorbitant prices for sugar will endanger the competitiveness of food products containing sugar," CIUS added.
CIUS, which represents 60 percent of sugar sold in the EU, warned that high sugar prices will lead to disinvestment and relocation of the industry outside the EU.
UNESDA warned that the entry of east European countries will result in growing sugar surpluses. However these could be partly absorbed by the soft drinks industry if prices were lower.
"Lower sugar prices would ultimately profit the consumer, who currently bears the cost of the sugar regime," it noted.
But extending the current sugar regime to east European countries would increase sugar prices, obstruct the development of the sugar industry and drive up inflation, it said.
